p: Para-influenza belongs to species of genus Paramyxovirus from family of Paramyxoviridae which are commonly called human parainfluenza viruses (HPIVs). This is a group of viruses that causes upper and lower respiratory illnesses and closely resembles common cold. Para-influenza viruses differ from RSV as it can re-infect the host and this event can lead to infections of upper respiratory tract [ 25]. The parainfluenza includes Parainfluenza virus type 1 (or Para 1) that causes laryngotracheobronchitis in infants and children. Further, Para influenza type 2 whose clinical manifestations resemble those of Para 1, but with less danger for hosts as compared to the type 1. Para influenza virus type 3 can lead to pneumonia, as well as bronchiolitis, with major adverse effects inflicting to infants below six months of age. Para influenza virus type 4 is rarer than the other types and clinical manifestations are not detected easily [ 26].
